qas.question: What is an example of secular Northern Brick Gothic architecture from the 14th century?
When was Brussels Town Hall built?
What is the name of the secular building in Spain which was constructed for the purpose of silk exchange?

answers.text: the Llotja de la Seda of Valencia

qas.question: What is the name of the 13th-century town hall constructed to host the offices of the republic of Siena?
Impressive public secular architecture can also be found in what other Italian city?
What is an example of secular Northern Brick Gothic architecture from the 12th century?
When was Brussels Town Hall hidden?

plausible_answers.text: the Llotja de la Seda of Valencia

qas.question: What is the name of the secular building in space which was constructed for the purpose of silk exchange?
What is the name of the 18th-century town hall constructed to host the offices of the republic of Siena?
What is the only Italian city with public secular architecture?

context: Secular Gothic architecture can also be found in a number of public buildings such as town halls, universities, markets or hospitals. The Gdańsk, Wrocław and <a0_0><b5_0>Stralsund town halls<b5_0/><a0_0/> are remarkable examples of northern Brick Gothic built in the late 14th centuries. The Belfry of Bruges or Brussels Town Hall, <a1_0>built <b6_0>during the 15th century<b6_0/><a1_0/>, are associated to the increasing wealth and power of the bourgeoisie in the late Middle Ages; by the 15th century, the traders of the trade cities of Burgundy had acquired such wealth and influence that they could afford to express their power by funding lavishly decorated buildings of vast proportions. This kind of expressions of secular and economic power are also found in other late mediaeval commercial cities, including <a2_0><b7_0>the Llotja de la Seda of Valencia<b7_0/><a2_0/>, Spain, a purpose built silk exchange dating from the 15th century, in the partial remains of Westminster Hall in the Houses of Parliament in London, or <a3_0><b8_0>the Palazzo Pubblico<b8_0/><a3_0/> in Siena, Italy, a 13th-century town hall built to host the offices of the then prosperous republic of Siena. Other Italian cities such as <a4_0><b9_0>Florence<b9_0/><a4_0/> (Palazzo Vecchio), Mantua or Venice also host remarkable examples of secular public architecture.
